main event: A circular object, the size of a pea, with a red, bluish-white, and green tail, was observed for 2-3 seconds in Fairbanks, Alaska on December 29, 1956.
interesting points: The object was initially thought to be a balloon or aircraft, but was later determined to likely be a flare fired by unknown persons in the area.
There were multiple witnesses, including two tower operators and a pilot, who had reported seeing similar flare-like activity in the area in the past.
The local police had received reports from residents living in the ridge area about having flares and firing them, but had been unable to apprehend the responsible individuals.

The sighting occurred at an altitude of approximately 20 degrees elevation and an azimuth of 170 to 290 degrees true, with the object arcing to the right and downward before going behind a hill or hitting the ground.
result: Likely a flare fired by unknown persons
sighted object: Circular object, size of a pea, with a red, bluish-white, and green tail
witnesses: Two tower operators, a pilot, and other residents in the area
photographs: No photographs were included in the report
